1.2: Path segment types.

Creates a path object. A path is a sequence of segments and may be open or closed. Path uses the EVEN-ODD fill rule for determining the interior of the path. A path must start with a moveTo command.

A "simple" path does not contain any arcs and may be transformed using the transform method.
Creates a copy of the given path, replacing arcTo with arcToAsCurves. The resulting path is simplified and can be transformed.
The path to simplify.
A new simplified path.
Returns the number of points for a segment type.
The segment type.
The number of points.

Creates a path object. A path is a sequence of segments and may be open or closed. Path uses the EVEN-ODD fill rule for determining the interior of the path. A path must start with a moveTo command.

A "simple" path does not contain any arcs and may be transformed using the transform method.
Appends another path to the end of this path.
The path to append.
This path.

Adds a path command to draw an arc centered at the point (cx, cy) with radius rx along the x-axis and ry along the y-axis from startAngle through extent degrees. Positive rotation is in the direction from positive x-axis to positive y-axis.
Use arcTo or arcToAsCurves instead.
X coordinate of center of ellipse.
Y coordinate of center of ellipse.
Radius of ellipse on x axis.
Radius of ellipse on y axis.
Starting angle measured in degrees from the positive x-axis.
The span of the arc in degrees.
If true, the starting point of the arc is connected to the current point.
The path itself.

Adds a path command to draw an arc starting at the path's current point, with radius rx along the x-axis and ry along the y-axis from startAngle through extent degrees. Positive rotation is in the direction from positive x-axis to positive y-axis.

This method makes the path non-simple.
Radius of ellipse on x axis.
Radius of ellipse on y axis.
Starting angle measured in degrees from the positive x-axis.
The span of the arc in degrees.
The path itself.
Same as arcTo, but approximates the arc using bezier curves. .* As a result, this method does not affect the simplified status of this path. The algorithm is adapted from java.awt.geom.ArcIterator.
Radius of ellipse on x axis.
Radius of ellipse on y axis.
Starting angle measured in degrees from the positive x-axis.
The span of the arc in degrees.
The path itself.
Clears the path.
The path itself.
A copy of this path.
Adds a path command to close the path by connecting the last point to the first point.
The path itself.
Creates a transformed copy of this path. The path is simplified #createSimplifiedPath prior to transformation.
The transformation to perform.
A new, transformed path.
Adds points to the path by drawing cubic Bezier curves. Each curve is specified using 3 points (6 coordinates) - two control points and the end point of the curve.
The coordinates specifying each curve in sets of 6 points: [x1, y1] the first control point, [x2, y2] the second control point and [x, y] the end point.
The path itself.
Adds points to the path by drawing cubic Bezier curves. Each curve is specified using 3 points (6 coordinates) - two control points and the end point of the curve.
The coordinates specifying each curve in sets of 6 points: [x1, y1] the first control point, [x2, y2] the second control point and [x, y] the end point.
The path itself.

Iterates over the path calling the supplied callback once for each path segment. The arguments to the callback function are the segment type and an array of its arguments.

The LINETO and CURVETO arrays can contain multiple segments of the same type. The number of segments is the length of the array divided by the segment length (2 for lines, 6 for curves).

As a convenience the ARCTO segment also includes the end point as the last two arguments: rx, ry, fromAngle, extent, x, y.
The function to call with each path segment.
Returns the coordinates most recently added to the end of the path.
An array containing the ending coordinates of the path of the form [x, y].
Returns an array of all arguments for the segments of this path object, in order. The returned array is a copy; modifications are not reflected in the Path object.
Returns an array of the number of times each segment type repeats in this path, in order. The returned array is a copy; modifications are not reflected in the Path object.

Returns an array of the segment types in this path, in the order of their appearance. Adjacent segments of the same type are collapsed into a single entry in the array. The returned array is a copy; modifications are not reflected in the Path object.
Whether the path is empty.
Returns true if this path contains no arcs. Simplified paths can be created using createSimplifiedPath.
True if the path contains no arcs.
Adds points to the path by drawing a straight line to each point.
The coordinates of each destination point as x, y value pairs.
The path itself.
Adds points to the path by drawing a straight line to each point.
The coordinates of each destination point as x, y value pairs.
The path itself.
Adds a point to the path by moving to the specified point. Repeated moveTo commands are collapsed into a single moveTo.
X coordinate of destination point.
Y coordinate of destination point.
The path itself.
Transforms the path. Only simple paths are transformable. Attempting to transform a non-simple path will throw an error.
The transformation to perform.
The path itself.
